women_leaders.name: Dr. Fei-Fei Li
women_leaders.title: Co-Director, Stanford HAI
women_leaders.bio: Pioneer in AI and computer vision, creator of ImageNet. Co-director of Stanford's Human-Centered AI Institute.
achievements: Former VP/Chief Scientist of AI at Google Cloud

women_leaders.name: Dr. Timnit Gebru
women_leaders.title: Founder, DAIR Institute
women_leaders.bio: Leading voice in AI ethics and algorithmic bias. Founder of Distributed AI Research Institute (DAIR).
achievements: Named one of TIME's 100 Most Influential People

women_leaders.name: Dr. Joy Buolamwini
women_leaders.title: Founder, Algorithmic Justice League
women_leaders.bio: Computer scientist and digital activist working on algorithmic bias and facial recognition ethics.

women_leaders.name: Dr. Cynthia Breazeal
women_leaders.title: Director, MIT Media Lab Personal Robots Group
women_leaders.bio: Pioneer in social robotics and human-robot interaction. Creator of Jibo, the world's first social robot.

women_leaders.name: Dr. Ayanna Howard
women_leaders.title: Dean of Engineering, Ohio State University
women_leaders.bio: Robotics engineer and educator, former NASA researcher specializing in autonomous systems.

women_leaders.name: Rumman Chowdhury
women_leaders.title: CEO, Humane Intelligence
women_leaders.bio: Data scientist focused on algorithmic fairness and responsible AI. Former Twitter ML Ethics lead.

women_leaders.name: Dr. Kate Crawford
women_leaders.title: Research Professor, USC & Co-founder, AI Now Institute
women_leaders.bio: Leading scholar on social implications of AI. Author of 'Atlas of AI'.
achievements: Co-founded AI Now Institute at NYU

women_leaders.name: Dr. Rediet Abebe
women_leaders.title: Assistant Professor, UC Berkeley
women_leaders.bio: Computer scientist using AI and algorithms to understand and address social inequality.
achievements: Co-founder, MD4SG (Mechanism Design for Social Good)

scholarships.name: Women Techmakers Scholars Program
scholarships.eligibility: Women studying computer science or related field

scholarships.name: Break Through Tech AI Program
scholarships.eligibility: Women and non-binary students in NYC area

scholarships.name: AI4ALL Summer Program
scholarships.eligibility: High school students from underrepresented groups

mentorship_programs.name: Connected Women in AI
mentorship_programs.description: 1-on-1 mentorship pairing women in tech with AI leaders

mentorship_programs.name: TechGirls Mentorship
mentorship_programs.description: Technology mentorship for young women aged 15-17

mentorship_programs.name: Girls Who Code Alumni Program
mentorship_programs.description: Ongoing mentorship for GWC alumni entering workforce

mentorship_programs.name: Black in AI Mentorship
mentorship_programs.description: Mentorship for Black AI researchers and practitioners

mentors.name: Maya Patel
mentors.story: I immigrated from India at 25 with a pharmacy degree and $500. Transitioning to AI felt impossible—I had no CS background and faced constant doubt. But I leveraged my healthcare domain expertise, took evening coding bootcamps, and built a portfolio of healthcare projects. Today, I lead a team building AI diagnostic tools. My advice: Your 'non-traditional' background is your superpower. Domain expertise + AI = unstoppable combination.

mentors.name: Keisha Williams
mentors.story: Growing up in South Side Chicago, I never saw anyone who looked like me in tech. I studied economics, not CS, and felt like an imposter when I started coding. After 8 years in traditional finance, I pivoted to AI at 30. The transition was hard—I faced bias, doubt, and loneliness. But I found Black in AI community, got mentors who believed in me, and now I'm paying it forward. You belong here. Your perspective is exactly what AI needs.

mentors.name: Dr. Sofia Rodriguez
mentors.story: Raised by a single mother in Mexico City, I was the first in my family to attend university. I earned a PhD in Computer Science while working night shifts to support my family. As a Latina woman in tech, I've faced everything—accent bias, being mistaken for admin staff, having my ideas credited to male colleagues. But I persisted. I'm now a Director at Amazon leading recommendation AI. My message: Your accent is an asset (bilingual = competitive edge!), your struggle builds resilience, and we need more Latinx voices in AI leadership.

mentors.name: Jennifer Chen
mentors.story: Immigrant from Taiwan, I faced the 'bamboo ceiling'—technically excellent but overlooked for leadership. For years, I was the 'quiet Asian girl' who did brilliant work but got no credit. I learned to advocate loudly for myself, took improv classes to improve communication, and strategically built allies. Breaking into product management from engineering at 35 felt late, but it was my breakthrough. Now I lead product strategy for autonomous vehicles. Asian women: technical excellence alone won't get you promoted. Visibility + advocacy = advancement.

mentors.name: Sarah Thompson
mentors.story: After having twins, I took a 4-year career break. Returning to tech felt terrifying—my skills were outdated, I had a resume gap, and I was competing with younger candidates. I started by taking free online courses during nap times, contributed to open source projects, and built a portfolio on GitHub. I didn't hide my career break—I framed it as 'gained project management skills raising twins!' Now I run my own ML consulting firm helping small businesses adopt AI. Career breaks don't disqualify you—they give you perspective that makes you better.

mentors.name: Dr. Amara Okafor
mentors.story: Born in Nigeria, educated in the UK, working in the USA—I'm a triple immigrant navigating three cultures. As a Black woman with a PhD in medical AI, I've been called 'too aggressive' when advocating for my ideas (code for 'uppity Black woman'). I've had my credentials questioned, my leadership undermined, and been paid 20% less than white male peers for the same role. But I didn't let bias define me. I documented everything, found allies in HR, and negotiated fiercely. Now I'm CAO at Mayo Clinic, building AI that works for ALL patients, not just those represented in biased datasets. Fight for your worth—you ARE qualified.

mentors.name: Priya Sharma
mentors.story: I was a high school teacher in Mumbai who saw firsthand how one-size-fits-all education failed students. With no tech background and no funding, I taught myself to code at 28, built an AI-powered personalized learning platform on weekends, and pitched it to 100+ investors. 99 said no. One said yes. That was 4 years ago. Today, LearnAI serves 50,000 students across India. As a woman founder in India's male-dominated tech ecosystem, I faced investors asking 'Where's your technical co-founder?' (I AM the technical founder!) and 'Who will watch your kids?' (My husband and I split childcare 50/50). To aspiring women founders: You don't need permission. Build it, launch it, prove them wrong.

mentors.name: Maria Gonzalez
mentors.story: Daughter of migrant farmworkers in California, I was the first to finish high school, let alone college. I studied business (not CS!) and worked retail for 5 years before discovering data science. At 27, I took a massive pay cut to join a data science bootcamp, living in my car for 3 months to save money. The bootcamp was intense—I was one of only 2 Latinas in a cohort of 40. I felt out of place, struggled with imposter syndrome, but my retail experience became my edge. I understood customer behavior intuitively. Now I lead retail AI projects at Target. To first-gen students: Your 'non-traditional' path is your advantage. Use it.
